titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Hartshorne, Parker, Saltar, Williams, and Wardell family genealogy notes 1973.117
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-12-19 15:51:13 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Hartshorne, Parker, Saltar, Williams, and Wardell family genealogy notes
did.abstract: The Hartshorne, Parker, Saltar, Williams, and Wardell family genealogy notes span the period 1678 to 1861 and were compiled by Elizabeth Hartshorne Williams from the family bibles of the five families represented in the notes. The notes list births, deaths, and marriages of various family members residing in New York City and New Jersey.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The notes were formally accessioned in 1973.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Hartshorne, Parker, Saltar, Williams, and Wardell family genealogy notes, 1973.117, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hartshorne, Parker, Saltar, Williams, and Wardell family genealogy notes span the period 1678 to 1861 and were compiled by Elizabeth Hartshorne Williams from the family bibles of the five families represented in the notes. The notes list births, deaths, and marriages of various family members residing in New York City and New Jersey.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
